There's still a disconnect between the way most economists think about money and the reality. I'm sure this is due in large part to Minton Friedman. While PK points out the liquidity trap very well, the language never seems to differentiate between the liquidity of the banks and the liquidity of the consumers.

Brad has pointed this out in the past, but his solution is that banks need relax their lending standards to allow M2 to take up the slack provided by MB. This is not a view that is compatible with the idea of 'equitable growth' that his think tank blog claims to advocate.

There is still a lot of confusion out there. It is clear that Brad and those he talks to care about inequality, but they don't show it. I'm pretty sure it is because they are confused. That confusion is probably caused by the history of economics in this country. There just isn't anyone in the field with an objective enough view to point out the major disconnect in their values and their policy ideas.

Everyone seems to keep going back to conventional ideas, and this is not a time for conventional ideas. It also isn't a time for pie in the sky ideas. It is a time for practical ideas based upon new insights.

The monetary system can remain much as it is for now, but without the model that shows you the other necessary requirements, I think everyone will continue to fail.

I know a real model will be given due consideration, and the required policies will flow quite obviously from it…

If you compare gross water use to residential water use, your figures are within the range of accurate.  San Francisco's gross water use in G/P/D  for 2014 was 98 - better than California's overall average of 197 G/P/D - and very close to Santa Fe's 92. When only residential consumption is considered, San Francisco Water Power& Sewer estimatedthe G/P/D at 49 for 2014, but indicated there is tremendous variation from place to place and among users. Household use tends to decline when high use activities are transferred to commercial venues, i.e., laundry is sent out;showers are taken in gyms, etc.

Apples and oranges.  You can't self righteously boast of using less water in the cool, coastal temperature of Silicon Valley while Santa Fe (or Palm Springs) use much more water for the same purpose due to hotter weather and evaporation and evapotranspiration of water from plants.

We have a home in Mexico ( Baja California North) we haul in all our water from a well a few miles away. So we know how much water we use on the average.

Our average is about 30 gallons per day per person. Including making our own drinking water, laundry and bathing. We have a separate "gray water system" and that water is used for trees and flowers around the yard. Our water costs $20 U.S. (Plus the cost of hauling it) per 1000 gallons.

So it is possible to reduce usage if the rules are changed to allow sensible water usage. This has not happened yet.most of SoCal's reclaimed water flows to the sea and is not reused at all.

The water waisted on the LA River is just one example!

The chart shows Santa Fe "reducing" to *only* 92 gal/person/day.  That is an exorbitant amt.  San Francisco uses 40+ G/P/D.  I live in a detached house in Silicon Valley with back yard and a native CA front yard and our family of 4 avgs. 28 G/P/D

Ironic, isn't it, that parents will refuse to vaccinate healthy children from the utterly unfounded fear that it causes autism, yet here we are discussing saving the terribly premature when that is the known cause of autism.

"Premature babies are often born to very young mothers or women with little to no prenatal care."

This is MRS. redsquirrel--You should not make generalizations like this. I was far from young (31) nor did I have little to no prenatal care. I took every precaution and had a complicated pregnancy. This was not a fertility drug-induced pregnancy, nor was it a multiple pregnancy. This was a single child pregnancy that went very wrong medically. Premature births are an equal opportunity annoyer. They know no socio-economic background.

My son also was born premature, at 31 weeks, and I, too, was struck by how absent the parents of other premature babies were. The NICU nurses told me that many had been born to very young, poor mothers who could not afford or figure out how to get back to the NICU to be with their children. So the extremely busy NICU nurses spent extra time holding and touching the babies, because, I was told, mothering was key to their survival. The children without attentive mothers tended to languish and die. The ones that did survive were turned over to their relatives, sometimes the grannies, after having been raised in the NICU sometimes for months, according to the nurses.
My son had a high APGAR score for a preemie -- a six. He was not intubated; he had no complications, and he gained weight steadily. Still, it was a nightmare for the month he was in the NICU. For the next several years, his development was delayed. My pediatrician told me it's a myth that preemies catch up in a year if there are no complications. It takes years. My son is now 17, planning to major in computer science or engineering in college. So I dunno. Before his birth, I would questioned the point of intensive medical care for preemies. But from the moment he was born, I was committed to him and I would have fought for the best care for him. As for those babies who were being treated and mothered and kept alive by NICU nurses, I can only hope that their families ended up appreciating them.

As someone who has had a premature baby...I am not sure I would want that for my child. I just don't know. We were 'lucky' and my son was born at exactly 32 weeks. There were babies much smaller and sicker than my son. They were on ventilators, had surgeries. Premature babies are often born to very young mothers or women with little to no prenatal care. My son was often the only baby with a parent at his crib for days on end. I don't know how we could have done that if we had had an older child at home.

When I did talk to another mother or grandmother they were often overwhelmed at the idea of how they were going to provide care for their sick baby at home. Cerebral Palsy, blindness, ADD, autism, retardation, we were constantly warned to prepare for all of it. My husband and I were lucky enough to have health insurance but we still had to pay thousands. It took years to pay off. I don't know how we would have coped with more major medical expenses after leaving the NICU.

Some of the kids in the NICU with my son went on to live very limited lives and their families have faced huge financial and emotional challenges. If we commit to saving sicker and smaller preemies, I hope we, as a society are ready to support them just as much when the leave the NICU because they are going to need it. It is going to be a lifetime of medical care.

Conveyance losses can be due to evaporation or seepage. Seepage recharges the groundwater, which is not an actual "loss" of water, even though the term "Conveyance Loss" is used in water balances.  Simply put, it's the difference between what is sent to a customer and what they actually receive when it gets there; more of an accounting thing.  Depending where the water is travelling, the seepage can be beneficial, but in your case (in SF) it's not.  Just FYI.

outis -- amniocentesis to test for birth defects is normally done around week 16.  And your claim that most late term abortions are conducted because of concern about birth defects is disputed.  Many women who wait are simply wavering on whether to get an abortion.

FYI, second trimester abortions make up an *extremely* small percentage of total abortions in the US. There are only a few facilities in the entire country that perform them, and women often have to get physician referrals and travel to another state. These are not spur-of-the-moment decisions.

Please provide some evidence to support that these are cases of women "not being able to make up their minds". All of the information I've read to date suggests that, in the *vast* majority of cases, most second trimester abortions are in fact due to medical problems with the mother or the fetus. There are plenty of medical issues that may not become apparent until later in pregnancy (e.g., fetal abnormalities discovered in scans, cancer diagnoses, life-threatening problems with the placenta, etc.)

Also, a certain percentage of these abortions happen in sad situations of rape or incest involving a minor, where the pregnancy isn't discovered until the more advanced stages.

I 'm not all that concerned with the ramifications for abortion because I don't have a lot of sympathy for women who delay the abortion decision until so close to the point of viability. My greater concern is why all the time, effort, and money is being poured into treatment of premies who have little chance of survival.  It seems like the flip side of expensive treatment of the elderly with little hope of prolonging their lives.
